projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ACT For Setling of the MILITIA OF THE Commonwealth OF ENGLAND.

p.hi: ORdered by the Parliament, That this Act be forthwith Printed and Publi≈øhed.

div.p: London, Printed by Edward Husband and John Field, Printers to the Parliament of England. 1650.

div.head: AN ACT For Setling of the MILITIA OF The Commonwealth of England.
div.p:
THe Parliament of England finding it nece≈ø≈øary, That the Commonwealth be put into a po≈øture of Defence, for the pre≈øervation of the Peace and Liberties of the People, after ≈øo much Blood and Trea≈øure ≈øpent in the obtaining thereof, again≈øt the Endeavors, Con≈øpiracies and Practi≈øes of divers Parties and Intere≈øts, differing in them≈øelves, yet united under ≈øeveral ≈øpecious pretences, all tending to the utter overthrow of the Safety of the Nation: And although acknowledging (which they de≈øire with all thankfulne≈øs may ever be remembred) That De≈øigns of this nature, Almighty God, by a high and merciful hand of Providence, hath u≈øually bla≈øted and brought to nought; yet judging it requi≈øite, That the Commonwealth be not wanting to it ≈øelf in the u≈øe of means tending to its own pre≈øervation and ju≈øt Defence, and conceiving it their duty to make fitting provi≈øion accordingly, with a dependance upon the ≈øame Divine Goodne≈øs for
a Ble≈øsing upon their Endeavors, Hold fit to Ordain and Enact, and be it Enacted and Ordained by this pre≈øent Parliament, and by the Authority thereof, That the Commi≈øsioners for the Militia in the ≈øeveral Counties and places of England and Wales, which now are, or hereafter ≈øhall be appointed by the Parliament or Councel of State, according to Order of Parliament in that behalf, in their ≈øeveral precincts and places, ≈øhall ob≈øerve and put in execution the≈øe In≈øtructions following:

FIr≈øt, The ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners, or any three or more of them, re≈øiding in the ≈øeveral counties, cities or Towns, &c. ≈øhall meet the fir≈øt Tue≈øday in every Moneth in ≈øome convenient place within their re≈øpective counties, cities and towns, and ≈øo from time to time, or oftner if need ≈øhall ≈øo require, within their ≈øeveral limits, &c. at ≈øuch time and place as ≈øhall be in that behalf appointed.

Secondly, The ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners and every of them, who have not already taken it, are before they act upon the≈øe In≈øtructions, to Sub≈øcribe the late Engagement appointed by the Parliament, To be true and faithful to the Commonwealth of England, as it is now E≈øtabli≈øhed, without a King or Hou≈øe of Lords, in the pre≈øence of any three of the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners; and then any two or more of them are to cau≈øe the ≈øame Engagement to be Sub≈øcribed before them, or any two ≈øuch per≈øons as by the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any two or more of them ≈øhall be appointed, by ≈øuch Colonels, Lieutenant Colonels, Majors and Captains, and by ≈øuch other Officers, Troopers and common Soldiers, whom they ≈øhall think fit
to be tru≈øted with Commands or Arms; and then the ≈øaid Field-Officers and Captains which have not been already Commi≈ø≈øionated and Approved of by the Councel of State, are to be recommended by the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners, or any three or more of them, to the ≈øaid Councel, to have Commi≈øsions, if they ≈øhall approve of them; which being granted, Then any three or more of the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners may grant Commi≈ø≈øions to the inferior Officers, which are fir≈øt to be recommended to them by ≈øuch Field Officer or Officers (or where none ≈øuch are, by ≈øuch Captains re≈øpectively as are Commi≈ø≈øionated as afore≈øaid) for their approbation, and if they approve of them, they are to grant them Commi≈ø≈øions accordingly. Provided, That the Councel of State, as they ≈øee occa≈øion, may alter or change the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners; and al≈øo Colonels, Lieutenant Colonels, Majors, Captains, or other Officers, and put other fit per≈øons in their rooms.

Thirdly, The ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners or any two of them, are by all good ways and means to inform them≈øelves, and from time to time to take from others Informations, and Examinations upon Oath (which Oath they have hereby power to admini≈øter) of all Con≈øpiracies, De≈øigns, Practi≈øes, ≈øecret and ≈øu≈øpitious Meetings of di≈øaffected per≈øons, whether expre≈ø≈øed by words or actions, ≈øpoken, printed, preached, written or publi≈øhed where≈øoever, again≈øt the Peace and Welfare of the Commonwealth, by ≈øecuring, di≈øper≈øing, or committing to pri≈øon the parties whom they finde to be e≈øpecially active and dangerous, or to u≈øe any other lawful ways and means for the di≈øper≈øing or ≈øecuring of them, in
order to be brought to Iu≈øtice as they ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe.

Fourthly, The ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, are authorized and required to di≈øarm and ≈øecure (by Impri≈øonment or otherwi≈øe) all Papi≈øts, and other ill-affected per≈øons that have of late appeared, or ≈øhall declare them≈øelves in their words or actions again≈øt this pre≈øent Parliament, or again≈øt the pre≈øent Government E≈øtabli≈øhed; or have or ≈øhall hold corre≈øpondency with Charls Stuart, the Son of the late King, or any of his party, or with any other per≈øon or Nation, tending to the Di≈øturbance, Subver≈øion or Alteration of this pre≈øent Government; or have or ≈øhall mini≈øter any Supplies to the Enemies of the Commonwealth; or rai≈øe, or endeavored the rai≈øing of any Tumults, Mutinies or In≈øurrections, and to cau≈øe them to be dealt with according to Law, and their ≈øeveral demerits.

Fifthly, That any three or more of the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall have full Power and Authority to charge any per≈øon with Hor≈øe and Arms, in the ≈øame county, ≈øhire, city or Town Corporate, where his, her or their u≈øual place of re≈øidence is or hath been, having re≈øpect unto, and not exceeding the limitations and proportions hereafter mentioned; that is to ≈øay, No per≈øon ≈øhall be charged with Hor≈øe and Arms, unle≈øs ≈øuch per≈øon have the yearly Revenue of Two hundred pounds per annum, or have a Per≈øonal E≈øtate of Two thou≈øand pounds in Goods or Moneys, or an E≈øtate equivalent thereunto, and ≈øo proportionably, as the Commi≈øsioners in their di≈øcretion ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe and think rea≈øonable; Nor ≈øhall any per≈øon be charged with a Dragoon-hor≈øe and Arms,
unle≈øs ≈øuch per≈øon have the yearly Revenue of Two hundred marks per annum, or who ≈øhall be worth Two thou≈øand marks in moneys, or other Per≈øonal E≈øtate, or an E≈øtate equivalent: And the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners are not to charge any per≈øon with finding of a whole Foot-Arms, that hath not a yearly Revenue of Twenty pounds per annum, or a Per≈øonal E≈øtate of Two hundred pounds in Goods or Moneys; And after the afore≈øaid Rates proportionably, for a greater or le≈ø≈øer Revenue or E≈øtate, it ≈øhall be lawful to and for the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, to impo≈øe the finding and providing of Hor≈øe and Arms as afore≈øaid, by joyning two, three, or more per≈øons together in the charge, as to their judgements ≈øhall appear mo≈øt conducible to the Service of the Commonwealth. Provided, That no per≈øon who hath not Ten pounds a year in Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, Lea≈øehold or Copyhold, or a Per≈øonal E≈øtate worth Two hundred pounds, ≈øhall be compellable to contribute in finding Foot-Arms as afore≈øaid; And that no per≈øon who hath not One hundred pounds per annum in Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, Lea≈øe-hold or Copyhold, ≈øhall be compellable to contribute in finding a Hor≈øe with Arms, or a Dragoon: And the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, have power to hear and examine Complaints upon Oath (which Oath they have hereby power to admini≈øter) and to give redre≈øs as there ≈øhall be cau≈øe.

Sixthly, The ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, are to take care that ≈øuch Hor≈øe and Arms as are ≈øo charged, and to be provided as afore≈øaid (and all ≈øuch other Hor≈øe and Arms as they ≈øhall hold fit to make u≈øe of for the ≈øervice
of the Commonwealth) upon all occa≈øions of Mu≈øter and Service, and during the time of any In≈øurrection or Inva≈øion in their re≈øpective counties, cities, &c. be put into the hands of ≈øuch well-affected per≈øons, and fit for War, as the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them ≈øhall approve of; which per≈øon and per≈øons are hereby required to ≈øerve with ≈øuch Hor≈øes and Arms accordingly; and that ≈øuch per≈øons be Li≈øted, Trained and Mu≈øtered in ≈øeveral Troops and Companies, and formed into Regiments: And the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners or any three of them, are hereby authorized and required to cau≈øe the ≈øaid Forces to be drawn out, and u≈øed for Suppre≈ø≈øing and Re≈øi≈øting all Inva≈øions, In≈øurrections and Rebellions in their ≈øeveral Precincts within this Commonwealth, and to bring to condign puni≈øhment the Enemies of the ≈øame; And ≈øhall for that purpo≈øe from time to time keep corre≈øpondency, as occa≈øion ≈øhall be, with the chief Commanders of the Parliaments other Forces in the re≈øpective counties, cities or towns adjacent, and act and proceed further, as they ≈øhall from time to time receive Orders from the Parliament, or Councel of State ≈øetled by their Authority.

Seventhly, That the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners or any three or more of them in their ≈øeveral counties, &c. ≈øhall require and direct all per≈øons ≈øo charged with Hor≈øe and Arms as afore≈øaid, to allow Two ≈øhillings a day to the Troopers that ≈øerve with their Hor≈øe and Arms, for the maintenance of the Man and Hor≈øe, and Twelve pence a day to their Foot-Soldiers, for ≈øo many days as they ≈øhall be ab≈øent from their Dwellings and Callings by occa≈øion of Mu≈øter or Exerci≈øe; And for furni≈øhing
Drums, Colours, Trophees, Ammunition and other Emergencies, the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, ≈øhall have power to lay a ≈øitting Rate upon their re≈øpective counties, not exceeding in one whole year the proportion of one Moneths A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment in each county, after the Rate of Ninety thou≈øand pounds per Men≈øem, charged for pay of the Army; which Moneys are to be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, collected and paid, according to ≈øuch In≈øtructions as ≈øhall be given from time to time by the Councel of State, unto the Officers by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners to be appointed, under the Penalties, and by the ways and means in the Acts pre≈øcribed for the Ninety thou≈øand pounds per Men≈øem; And in ca≈øe of ≈øudden Exigence for Re≈øi≈øting or Suppre≈øsing of Inva≈øion or In≈øurrection, whereby occa≈øion will be to draw out ≈øuch Soldiers into actual Service, The per≈øons ≈øo charged as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall provide each their Soldier re≈øpectively, with pay in hand, not exceeding one Moneths pay, as ≈øhall be in that behalf directed by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, or any three or more of them: For repayment of which ≈øaid Moneys, and for ≈øatisfaction of the Commanders and Officers for their pay during ≈øuch time, not exceeding one Moneth as afore≈øaid, as they ≈øhall be with their Soldiers in ≈øuch ≈øaid actual Service, The Parliament doth hereby Declare, That provi≈øion ≈øhall be made for the ≈øame forth of the publique Trea≈øury, and like cour≈øe taken for pay and encouragement both of Officers and Soldiers, if they ≈øhall be continued upon longer actual Service, as is provided for the Army Forces under the immediate conduct and command of the Lord General.

Eighthly, The ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three
of them, may charge Carts, Waggons, Wains and Hor≈øes, for the carrying of Powder, Match, Bullet, and other Materials, allowing Two pence the mile outward onely to every ≈øuch Cart, Waggon and Wain ≈øo taken upon the marching of any Regiment, Company or Troop, upon occa≈øion of Inva≈øion, In≈øurrection, &c. and ≈øhall and may impri≈øon Mutiniers and di≈øordered per≈øons, and ≈øuch as do not their Duties as common Soldiers at the day of the Mu≈øter and Training, ≈øhall and may be by them puni≈øhed for every ≈øuch Offence, Five ≈øhillings, or Twenty days Impri≈øonment, without Bail or Mainprize; and when drawn out, and upon actual Service, occa≈øioned by any In≈øurrection, or Rebellion, or Inva≈øion, then to be ≈øubject during that time to the Rules, Orders and In≈øtructions mentioned in the Lord Generals In≈øtructions for Regulating his Army: And that the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three of them, ≈øhall have power to Fine ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall refu≈øe, neglect or delay to ≈øend in their Hor≈øe, Arms, Dragoons, Hor≈øe and Arms, and Foot-Arms, with their Riders and Soldiers, upon Summons, for not appearing at Mu≈øters and Training-days, the Fine not exceeding the ≈øum of Forty ≈øhillings for every ≈øuch offence; and to Fine parties for not appearing with their Hor≈øe and Arms upon any Rebellion, Inva≈øion and In≈øurrection, the ≈øame not exceeding Twenty pounds, and to be further puni≈øhed as the Parliament ≈øhall think fitting, by Seque≈øtration or otherwi≈øe; And in ca≈øe of refu≈øal of payment of the ≈øeveral Fines aforementioned, The ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, by Warrants under their Hands and Seals, are to cau≈øe the ≈øame to be levyed upon the Lands, Goods and Chattels of the party ≈øo offending,
having Ten days warning to pay in the ≈øaid Fine, before levy thereof be made; And ≈øhall and may Fine every Con≈øtable, or any other fit per≈øon, that ≈øhall be nominated and appointed by any three or more of the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners to levy the ≈øaid Fines, and ≈øhall neglect or refu≈øe to do the ≈øame; the ≈øaid Fine for any one Offence not to exceed Ten pounds, or to impri≈øon them until they have paid the ≈øaid Fine, or yielded obedience to their Commands: And the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners or any three or more of them, are to appoint for every Regiment a Mar≈øhal, to ≈øee the≈øe and all other Penalties again≈øt the≈øe ≈øeveral Offences, and their Offenders, as in this Act is expre≈ø≈øed, put in execution, as they ≈øhall receive Direction from time to time from any three or more of the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners; which Penalties ≈øo levyed, are to be accounted for the Service afore≈øaid, for the u≈øes of the emergent occa≈øions thereof in the re≈øpective counties, &c. the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners allowing ≈øuch Salary to the parties for puni≈øhing ≈øuch Offenders, and making ≈øuch Levies, as any three or more of the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners ≈øhall think fit from time to time to allow.

And it is Enacted and Declared by the Authority afore≈øaid, That all Power of Lord Lieutenants, and Deputy Lieutenants, and all former Power, Acts and Ordinances of Parliament, concerning the way of Rai≈øing the Militia by Trained, or Freehold-Bands, or Rates, or Taxes for them, ≈øhall from henceforth cea≈øe, and be no longer of any force or effect.

And la≈øtly, the ≈øaid Commi≈øsioners, Monethly or oftner, if there ≈øhall be occa≈øion, are to
give an accompt of their proceedings and actions to the Parliament or Councel of State.

Provided, That this Act, nor any thing contained therein, ≈øhall be in force for any longer term then the Fir≈øt day of February, which ≈øhall be in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred and fifty.
ORdered by the Parliament, That this Act be forthwith printed and publi≈øhed.
